critique: This executive order extends the duties of the Committee on Fair Employment Practice, originally established to prevent discrimination in defense industries during World War II, to include industries contributing to the transition to a peacetime economy. This suggests a focus on social inclusion and economic regulation to ensure fair employment practices. The order itself doesn't explicitly expand executive power, but rather continues existing duties. It doesn't directly address immigration, federalism, or national security vs. civil liberties. The ideological tilt is moderately liberal due to the emphasis on fair employment and government intervention in the economy to prevent discrimination.
